title: Beautiful Church
text: Located on the main square of Oia, this church with spotless white walls, blue some and a bell tower with six bells is an iconic image of Santorini. The inside of the church is also beautiful. A mass was on when we went in and it was such a peaceful atmosphere inside.

title: Beautiful place
text: Buildings painted spotless white, church domes painted blue, marble pathways with a view of the sea, all these make this area an ideal location to spend time. This place bursts with people during sunset. Lots of eateries and souvenir shops line the street.

title: Excellent view & service
text: We chose Imerovigli as the place to stay in Santorini, over Oia and Fira and zeroed in on Vista Mare suites, after reading a lot of reviews on tripadvisor. Glad we made that choice. Vista Mare is located at Gali square, the central point of Imerovigli. A few steps down from there takes you to the place. The view from our room was fantastic. It was a nice experience having breakfast sitting in the balcony, watching the caldera, the volcano and the boats on the sea. The room was clean and comfortable. Service was great with George there to take care of all our needs. There are nice restaurants nearby where you can have candle light dinner in the open. The bus stop is a short walk away from where buses connect to main points like Oia, Fira and Perivolos beach.

title: Nice choices
text: Had a nice lunch at this place. Good choices on the menu. Tasty food. Good service & comfortable seating

title: Early morning ferry to Santorini
text: We took a cab to go to the port to catch the World champion Jet Ferry to Santorini at 7.15 am. Reached here nearly an hour early. The cab dropped us just in front of the ferry, which was very convenient. We waited till 7pm when we were asked to board the ferry. The wait till then was painful. No place to sit, no toilet facility, no cafes open.

title: Dangerous cliff - tourists ignore warning
text: The walk to the beach down a steep slope alongside the cliff, is very slippery and dangerous. There is a warning sign warning tourists not to venture there due to frequent landslides. However, we found a lot of tourists including elderly people risking it. We went some way and turned back. So did many others. Not worth the risk. There is just a thin rope tied along the edge of the pathway. Just a rope ! That is not the level of safety you expect in an European country. Wonder why the Greece Tourism Department is allowing this. God forbid if a major landslide does happen, they may point to the warning sign and say 'didn't we warn you'. The travel agents are still selling this as a must go to location.

title: Nice boat trip
text: We were staying at Imerovigl from where we had an excellent view of the caldera. We took a tour by boat to the volcano island. The best part was the boat ride through the blue waters of the Aegean sea. Some of the views were as if from picture post cards. We docked at the volcano island made of black rocks and our tour guide took the people on a hike of the volcano. A handful of us chose to stay back on the boat and enjoy the breeze and the scenery. It was a morning well spent.

title: Black sand beach
text: A very long stretch of beach with black gravelly sand. The beach is clean and is lined with beach chairs and umbrellas. A variety of water sports are available. A number of restaurants are available in this area. A perfect location for dinner

title: Excellent Greek frozen yoghurt
text: Located on the Fira main Street which is full of eateries. There are a wide range of flavours to choose from and a variety of toppings. The youghurts were yummy. Prices are moderate and are as per weight.

title: Avoid
text: We went to Thirassia island as part of a one day tour to the volcanos, hot springs and oia. We landed at Thirassia around 1.30 pm and our tour guide recommended to all of us to have lunch at Labros. She said they serve the best sea food. Little did we realise that this was a set up. Labros is one of the five or six restaurants on the small rocky beach at Thirassia. First look itself was not very promising, but with most people on our tour headed there, prompted by the tour guide, we decided to try out the place. The sea food; we tried kalamari and some other fish, tasted bland with parts of it uncooked. Yuck ! There were cats roaming around the restaurant and eating leftovers. Yuck ! Surprised to find such a restaurant in Europe. Obviously, the tour guide is paid to direct tourists to them. If there was an option for zero rating, I would have given that

title: Excellent cafe
text: This is a small cafe on the beach at Thirasia island which serves coffe, ice creams and sandwiches. Tried all three and were excellent. Service was good and prices were moderate.

title: Birthday dinner
text: Went there to celebrate the birthday of a family member. The restaurant had arranged a nice cake as we had informed them in advance. Seating was comfortable and the ambience was nice. The burgers especially the brickhouse monster burger, sandwiches and rice bowl with chill chicken all tasted good

title: World Champion Jet Ferry from Athens to Santorini
text: Was slightly apprehensive about the ferry after reading some negative reviews on trip advisor. But our trip went off without a hitch. Our ferry was at 7.15 am and we reached the port about 45 minutes early. First they allowed the cars and two wheelers in, on to the ground floor of the ferry. At around 7 am, they asked passengers to come on board. There are racks on the ground floor, to store bags. The names of various islands where the ferry stops are marked on the racks. Take care to store your bags in the right rack (note Santorini is called Thira) or it might get offloaded at another port of call. Seating is on the upper deck as per the seat number on the ticket. The staff on the ferry will direct you to the right seating spot. The seats are ok, not that comfortable. Snacks and drinks are available for purchase. The ferry took more time than expected. We reached Santorini by 2.15 pm, a hour behind schedule. Would rate the whole experience as functional ie meeting the need. Nothing more nothing less

title: A bit hyped to be honest
text: For me,the sunset is always beautiful and the view of the setting sun from each place is unique. We were in Oia during summer and there were horses of people with their cameras and mobile phones out. It was jampacked. The sunset was beautiful but it was certainly not the best I have seen.

title: Excellent ambience
text: The first thing that hits you as you walk in is the well manicured garden. There are huts in the garden where you will be served. The ambience at night is very relaxing. Seating is also available inside the building but we chose to sit outside. The menu offers a wide range. We chose chicken clear soup and crab meat soup, Russian salad, chicken ghee roast, crunchy fish in tartar sauce, amis Jojo kebab, mutton koobiden and green apple mojito. The food tasted great and service was quick and efficient.

title: Good grilled food
text: Went there for dinner. Had spicy max leg and breast, pasta and smoothies. The grilled items were good. The pasta was average. Service was ok. Limited parking space is available in front of the building

title: Nice dinner buffet
text: The restaurant is on the top floor and the buffet dinner is laid out with live dinner. The spread is very good with soups, starters, salad and main course; both veg and non veg. There is a counter for live dosa and appam. Also a chaat counter. Desserts were good.

title: Great stay
text:
Very conveniently located at a walkable distance from the Acropolis museum & Acropolis and around two kilometres from Plaka and Syntagma square. We were provided with a map of the location and the nearby sights, which was very useful.

Our room had a balcony from where we had beautiful view of the Acropolis. The room was big and comfortable. The breakfast spread was nice. People at the reception and at the door were very courteous. We had a very pleasant stay

title: The symbol of Athens
text:
A few tips first. (1) Suggest you visit the Acropolis museum before visiting the Acropolis, to get a feel of the history of the ancient city. (2) Read up on the Acropolis online and download a map of the Acropolis on your mobile, before your visit. You don't need a tour guide. (3) if you are visiting Greece during summer like we did, keep in mind it is going to be very hot. Carry water and use sun cream. Proper walking shoes is a must since you have to climb stairs to reach the site. The climb is easy. No worries on that at all. (4) visit Acropolis in the evening, after 5.30 pm so that you can see the Parthenon lighted up. Also a good idea to escape the heat. (5) Buy a ticket online in advance, to beat the queue. Buy either a solo ticket or a combo ticket which covers Acropolis plus other historical sights of Athens

The visit to the Acropolis would take one and a half to two hours. Amazing to think how the Greek built a city on a hill, with such imposing structures with huge columns and beams, centuries ago

title: Smaller temple on the Acropolis
text: This is the first iconic temple to be built on the Acropolis and celebrates the victory of godess Athena. The structure is intact.

title: Temple of Athena & Posiedon
text: The temple which is associated with the mythological rivalry between Athena & Posiedon for control of the city of Athens, is located on the Acropolis, adjacent to the Parthenon. It is largely intact. A stand out feature of its architecture is the 'porch of the maidens' supported by six figures of maidens (known as caryatids), which act as columns.

title: Imposing entrance to the Acropolis
text: Propylea is the ornamental imposing entrance to the Acropolis. Part of it is intact. We are left wondering how the Greeks built such imposing structures with huge columns and beams, on top of a hill centuries ago.

title: Imposing Amphitheatre
text: This is a Roman amphitheatre built in stone on the slope of the Acropolis. This is the first structure we come across if we enter the Acropolis throught the main gate. This is the venue of the annual Athens festival and concerts are held here regularly.

title: Symbol of Greece
text:
The Parthenon is probably the most famous tourist symbol of Athens. Suggest visiting the Acropolis in the evening as we get to see Parthenon lighted up.

Originally built as a temple of godess Athena, this structure subsequently underwent transformations due to conquest of Athens by invaders. Thus, it got convered to a christian church under Byzantine rule and later into a mosque after the Ottoman invasion. Later, parts of the Parthenon were broken and transported to the London museum.

Renovation work of the Parthenon is currently on. It is a sight to see the structure up close and lighted up.

title: Part of the Trilogy of neo classical buildings
text: This one if the three buildings in neo classical style, located next to each other on Panepistimou street. The National library of Greece is on the left, the University of Athens in the middle and the Academy of Athens on the right. A landmark area of the city.

title: Great architecture
text: This is one of the three trilogy of buildings in neo classical style located next to each other along Panepistimiou street. The building has a pillar on each side with the figures of Appolo and Athena on top. Two statues, those of Socrates in a thinking pose and his disciple Plato writing on a plaque a plaque adorn the entrance to the building.

title: Great way to cover Athens by night
text: The private tour by car by Olive Sea Travel company and booked through TripAdvisor, is for 4 hours and is a great way to take in the major sights of Athens. We were picked up from our hotel at 5 pm. The driver spoke good english and gave a good intro of each location before dropping us off at each place. The tour is well spaced out and we have enough time at each location. The tour covered the Temple of Olympian Zeus, Arch of Hadrian, a visit to the Acropolis lit up in the night (entry closes at 7 pm in summer), Panathenaic stadium, Syntagma square & changing of the guards at the tomb of the unknown soldier, Palaka, the trilogy of buildings (University, Academy and the library) and Lycabettus Hill. We visited Athens in summer and it was very hot. So, this tour was ideal as it was in the evening when the temperature was moderate. In fact the best time to see Athens is after the lights are on.

title: A landmark
text: This gate is located just a couple of minute by walk from the temple of Olympian Zeus, by the side of a busy street. It was built to celebrate the arrival of the Roman emperor Hadrian. One of the prominent landmarks of the city of Athens. Just a photo stop unless you are deep into history

title: Nice area to spend an evening
text: Nice area filled with cafes and shops, at the foothills of the Acropolis. Vehicular traffic is not allowed and hence it is a nice walk through these streets to Monastiraki. The streets are filled with people and there is a nice buzz around

title: Visit to see changing of the guards
text: The Syntagma square is where celebrations and protests happen in Greece. I heard this name first as the centre of festivities, when Greece won Euro 2004. Suggest visiting the square at night. Every hour there is a very short changing of the guards ceremony at this square, at the tomb of the unknown soldier.

title: Not a priority unless you are a history buff
text: The few huge columns are connecting beams are all that remain at the site, which serves as a reminder of how magnificent the temple of Zeus, the father of Gods in Greek mythology might have been. Suggest you read up a bit about the temple before you visit the site as there is no information available at the site; no brochure or plaques detailing the history.

title: Beautiful night view of Athens
text: Went there around 9 pm. Got a nice view of the city by night including landmarks like the Parthenon and the Parliament building. There is a chapel at the top of the mount, which was closed at this time. The restaurant was open. There were groups of revellers and couples around with the police keeping a watchful eye.

title: Unique
text: This short ceremony happens every hour at the tomb of the unknown soldier, located in front of the Parliament building at Syntagma square. It is a simple affair which is unique in terms of the dress and footwear of the soldiers and their movements.

title: Sporting history
text: A must visit if you are a sports buff, to take in a bit of sporting history. The venue of the first moden Olympics, this stadium is built of marble. Pick up an audio guide at the entrance which explains the history pretty well. You have access to the track. Overall a nice feel to the visit.

title: Dinner at a tea lounge
text:
The place has a restaurant which serves limited menu and varities of Ceylon tea and a coffee shop outside, with a couple of benches open to sky. Have tried both. The coffee shop serves tea, coffee and snacks. Good place for a stop over to have a quick bite and a cup of tea.

The restaurant has a nice ambience with nice pencil sketches adorning the walls. The appam and stew combination was nice and so was the king fish which was served with salsa and rice. Prices of these were moderate. Not so for the Ceylon tea which while pricy, was a disappointment. Parking on the busy AKG centre to General Hospital road is a problem.

title: Ideal for a visit after the rainy season
text: The roads leading to this place are in good condition. Water level in the reservoir was down. Would be ideal to visit this place after the rainy season. There is a cafe which operates till around 7.30 pm and a paid toilet. Sadly, the children's park here is in a neglected state. A Devi temple is located right opposite the dam from where you can access the river. You can also feed the fish in the river. Car parking is available and is free

title: Excellent view from the top
text: A lift is available to take visitors up a few floors from where you have to climb a ladder to reach the top. The view from here is excellent. You can see the see fishing harbour, the masjid, the church and the Kovalam beach. The lighthouse compound is kept clean. Parking is an issue as the road leading to the lighthouse is narrow. So, you need to park at some distance

title: Nice ambience & food
text: We had cream of chicken soup, meen kurumulaku porichathu (fish), chicken perattu and Kerala parotta. The food was tasty. Seating was comfortable and ambience was nice. Service was good. The place has ample parking space.

title: Nice experience - a bit far from town
text: Stay in a cave hotel is a unique experience. Out room had four separate sections; a living area with sofa and TV, a bedroom with a huge comfy bed, a jacuzzi area and bathroom. The hotel has a pool and a terrace from where you can watch the sunset. The only disadvantage is that the hotel is in a remote area quite far from Gerome city centre and there are no restaurants nearby. Food at the hotel is costly. Service is very good.

title: Amazing
text:
Imagine a small city eight floors underground ! That is Kaymakli for you. Due to safety concerns, only four floors are open to the public. These underground dwellings dates back to the 7th century and has been used by the local population over different centuries as a means to protect themselves from invasion of the Arabs, Mongols and Romans as per the times.

This is certainly not for very senior citizens and those with claustrophobia, as we have to go through tunnels, some of them narrow. There are two tunnels where we have to squat and move forward. My thigh muscles were aching the next day. Keep in mind that once you enter a tunnel, you cannot turn back as there are people behind you. I am tall and hence was initially hesitant to go in, but got the confidence to do so, once I saw some tall and burly people go in. I am glad I did as the place is amazing. Wonder how they did it centuries back with primitive equipments.

title: Magnificent rock formations
text: The lunar landscape is a visual delight with a variety of rock formations. Many of these formations take an animal form or human form and it is fun to guess the formations. Camel, lizard, human hand with fingers, Napoleans hat, dolphin, love birds, the letter H are some of them. A must visit in Cappadocia.

title: Amazing work of nature
text: The unique terrain is a result of volcanic activity and wind erosion over centuries. Rock cut churches and dwellings, pigeon caves, fairy chimneys and valleys dot the area. Amazing work of nature. A sight to behold

title: Be extremely wary of marketing tricks
text:
If a tour guide recommends this place so that you get to see the local pottery making, keep in mind that is just a front and at the end of pottery making show, the people there will play tricks to put pressure on you to buy stuff, and that too costly ones.

As we walked in, we were seated and offered a welcome drink. Then, we witnessed pottery making using a spinning foot wheel. We were also shown the painting process and sample designs. We were then led to a large room where very costly pieces of ceramic ware were on display for sale. Keep on mind that they invite you to this room first and use their subtle selling skills to push you to buy some costly stuff promising 20% discount. If you show lack of interest they say 'let me try and help you' and then start reducing the price. Don't fall for it unless you really find something of interest. Otherwise just politely and firmly move on. In that case, they will take you to another room where the prices are lot lot cheaper. So, it is clear that they are doing it on purpose; show the costly items first and push you to buy them by offering discounts and if that doesn't work, show you the less costlier stuff.

Rating of 4 for the items on display, but overall rating of 3 considering the sales pitch / tricks

title: Work of nature
text: Fairy chimneys of different shapes formed out of volcanic activity and wind erosion over centuries, dot the Cappadocia landscape. There are quite a few sites where you can see them. My favourite places are Devrent Valley, Pasabag and Pigeon valley. A hot air balloon ride over the pigeon valley is a must do.

title: Unique landscape
text: The landscape of the huge valley was unique, with a lot of pigeon houses of various shapes and with the red soiled tablet plateau on one side. Ideal place for photographs. A must visit if you are in Cappadocia. The best way to see pigeon valley is to take a hot air balloon ride

title: Cappadocia guided tour
text:
Two of us took a two day guided tour of Cappadocia with Euphrates tours. The tour went as per schedule. A car, driver and an English speaking guide were with us during the two days. The guide Aylin was perfect. She was very professional and made a huge positive difference to the tour. She was very enthusiastic about showing us places and was very knowledgeable about the history of each place. Overlall, no cause for complaint.

Aylin

title: Fairy chimneys
text: A number of fairy chimneys with rock caps dot the area, which look like mushrooms. These were the dwellings of monks in the Byzantine era. There are twin and triple fairy chimneys. Recommend visiting this place either early morning or in the evening, to avoid the sun. We did the latter

title: Rock cut churches & frescos
text: This was the place of worship and living of Christian monks back in the 11th century. The area has a number of Rick cut churches, some of them at two levels. Each church has frescos, some of them are well preserved and are beautiful. Definitely a must visit

title: Brunch
text: Some of us had chicken soup and the others had lemon coriander soup with bread varieties. Main course of the buffet was appam, rice, nan and pulao with non veg options chicken, beef, fish (good but nothing outstanding) and a decent choice of veg options (bhindi curry, paneer and kappa were stand out items). Dessert spread had a good range of choices. Table service was good. The hotel has ample parking space.

title: A pilgrimage place
text: A place where people perform last rights of their departed relatives. Monthly and yearly bali for the departed are also performed here. A lot of sheds along the beach where people can do these rights. The place is secluded during the day. Would not suggest this beach as a tourist spot. The kollam beach is far more beautiful and vibrant

title: Below expectations
text: Started with Tom Kha chicken soup and honey chilli chicken. The chicken pieces in the soup were old and hard. The starter was ok but still a disappointment since it is one of their signature dishes. Moved on to black pepper fish and chicken sizzler with smoothies Pineapple & mango and strawberry and mango. The fish was yummy. The sizzler had chicken pieces which looked exactly like those in the honey chilli chicken except that there was no honey. Some boiled vegetables and cauliflower pieces made made up the sizzler. The smoothies were good. Overall did not measure up to our expectations.

title: A must visit in Kollam.
text: A lift is available to take you close to the top, from where there are two flights of stairs to reach the balcony of the lighthouse. The view from the top is superb. The lighthouse and premises are well kept (you need to keep your footwear outside). Kudos to the authorities for that. Parking facility is available for free. Entry fee is Rs.20 per person and there is nominal fee of Rs 10 if you want to take pictures with your mobile.

title: Nice beach. Well kept
text: Wide stretch of beach, shallow in parts. Coast guards are on the watch and they warn you if you venture beyond a point into the sea. The beach is overall clean. Nice to see a lot of kite flying activity.

title: Very good lunch
text: Had Non veg Thali lunch which was real value for money @ Rs.240 including tax. 16 dishes; 11 veg and 5 non veg (chicken curry & fry, fish curry, squid and netholi), Kerala parotta and rice. Ambience and service were good.

title: With a bit of care, could be better
text: Had dinner at Vega Dimora restaurant at this hotel. This is a vegetarian restaurant. We had tomato ginger soup, pineapple rasam soup and sweetcorn veg soup with idli chips and cutlet as starters. The soups felt watery. Main course was tomato oothappam, kothuparotta, appam, veg biriyani, veg stew, dragon paneer, veg kuruma, pickle and curd. The dragon paneer and kothuparotta were very good. Other items were just ok. Dessert was cheese cream cake which was not at all sweet and below par. Ordered items took unusually longer to arrive. Service was courteous.

title: Made out of a single rock
text: Amazing structure on top of the highest point in Cappadocia, with the rooms and passages carved out of a single stone. Ideal time to go there is in the evening, as there is quite a hike to reach the top.

title: Good Transit hotel
text: This hotel is located around 5 kms away from Chennai airport. Had booked a room and pick up from the aiport. We landed in Chennai close to midnight and found that the pick up had not arrived. Called the hotel and it seems that they forgot about it. So, we were left stating on the sidewalk outside the arrival hall for about 45 minutes for that car to arrive. Not a pleasant experience at this hour and after a long flight. After we got picked up, everything was fine. The hotel room was recently renovated and was nice and clean. (When you book, ask for the refurbished rooms). Had a nice sleep before our next flight. Breakfast menu was limited but whatever was available was fine.

title: Very comfortable stay
text: A big plus is the location in the Insadong shopping area, which also has a lot of restaurants. The metro station is a short walk from the hotel and so is the Changdeokgung Palace. The room was nice and clean and wifi worked fine. The breakfast spread is nice and service was good. Special mention about the front office stay who always greet you with a smile and a hello whenever you tep into the lobby. Check in and checkout were very fast. Overall, a very comfortable stay

title: Good choices at reasonable prices
text: We had vanilla with strawberry sauce, Maharaja Bhog and Butterscotch bliss and my favourite butterscotch stick dipped in chocolate. All the items were yummy. Prices were moderate.

title: Not up to expectations
text: Went there for dinner based on good reviews. Starters were achyan beef, fried chicken and paneer 65. All three were ok, nothing special. Main course was duck roast, koiyala fry, mathi fry, egg pepper fry, dal fry, parotta, puttu, veg fried rice. Out of the dishes the only item which stood out was duck roast. The two fish items were below par. Other items were ok. The sad part was that some of the items which looked visually appealing were average in terms of taste. Had tea which was excellent.

title: Well kept. Good place to buy plants
text: This botanical garden is very well maintained and has a wide collection of flowering plants, cactus, bonsai, crotons, lawn grass and items like plantain. Prices are much lower than those on the city. The road to the place is in very good condition. So the drive was smooth.
place: Kuzhipallam Botanical Garden and Research Centre

title: Not for talk people & those with breathlessness issues
text: Before you go into the tunnel, you have to keep your mobile, camera and other belongings in a locker (no photography allowed inside the tunnel). You then wear a helmet and walk into the tunnel. It is a steep slope for the first half a kilometre. From there on the slope is very mild but the tunnel gets narrow both in terms of height and width. That section is not for people who are claustrophobic. Six footers will find it a problem in this section as they will have to stoop to avoid hitting their head against the top of the tunnel. So, I went only till the first half a kilometre and turned back. Majority of the tourists did so. The climb back was slow and we saw several people facing issues of breathlessness. Thankfully, there are benches along the stretch where you can rest.

title: A must visit
text:
The DMZ is a buffer zone separating South and North Korea. The place is heavily fortified and at a check point, South Korean soldiers will stop your vehicle and check your passport. You can take a half day or a full day tour to DMZ from Seoul. I suggest the half day no shopping tour in the morning which takes you to all the places and gives you enough time to see each place, without wasting time on shopping.

The tour covers Imjingak Park where you can see the Freedom bridge and a locomotive riddled with more than 1,000 bullets, which serves as a grim reminder of the Korean war. You also get to see the 3rd infiltration tunnel built by North Koreans to try and infiltrate into South Korea. You can go down the sloping tunnel for some distance. After a while it gets cramped and head room is less for tall people (at anything point you can stop and come back). The next stop is the Dorasan observatory from where, using mounted binoculars, you can see North Korean military outpost and soldiers and a model village. The last stop is the Dorasan train station which is currently unused, and is a symbol of hope of the unification of the two Korea's.

During the time of our visit to Seoul, the JSA (panmunjeom) was closed for visitors. If it is open when you visit, don't miss it. Overall, the visit to DMZ was unique and a chilling reminder of the hostility between the two countries.

title: The hope of reunification
text: This station represents the hope of unification of the two Korea's. It is currently not in use and serves as a tourist spot. The big poster at the station says it all 'Not the last station from the South. But the first station towards North'.

title: A peep into North Korea
text: There is a mini theatre where you can watch a film on the Korean war. From the top floor of the observatory, we can see the North Korean outpost and their soldiers and a model village, through mounted binoculars.

title: Reminder of the Korean war
text: This was the first stop of our VIP half day morning tour of DMZ. We can see the Freedom bridge through which prisoners of war returned to South Korea. Also the hundreds of messages of peace and unification posted by South Koreans whose familes and friends have been separated from them and are now living in North Korea. Also on display is a steam locomotive riddled with more than 1,000 bullets, which serves as a grim reminder of the Koreannwar.

title: Convenient for KTX passengers
text: Located at the entry /exit point to the platforms for KTX trains at Seoul station. The place was crowded and there were long lines to order, so we used the electronic ordering system which was very user friendly and convenient. Food was the usual McD fare. The place is kept clean despite the rush.

title: Good food and seating
text: We dropped in for a late lunch and found the place almost to ourselves. Seating was nice, much better than outlets like KFC. We ordered crispy chicken and chicken burger and the food arrived quickly.

title: Nice souveniers
text: We were staying at Insadong and hence it was easy to take a round in the area in late evening. There are lots of shops with craft work and souveniers, street food and organised restaurants. We felt safe walking around at this hour.

title: Vibrant place, great street food
text: Had heard so much about this shopping area but what was on display went beyond all that. This is the place for korean beauty products. Lots and lots of street food joints and you will be spoilt for choices. The food looks visually appearing and everything we tried was yummy. The streets are choc a bloc with shoppers and there it is fun to just sit somewhere munching on the food and watch the world go buy. You can spend hours at this place. A must visit if you are in Seoul

title: Another palace if you have the time
text: This palace stands next to the Changdeokgung palace and is smaller and less impressive. There is a wall separating the two palaces, with a gate. The palace gardens are vast.

title: Nice palace & secret garden
text: This palace also has an extension which is called the secret garden. There is an additional fee of 5000 won to enter the secret garden, which has buildings set amidst trees and landscaping. The palace complex is vast and the guided tour took a lot of time. The guide was excellent in explaining the history and took pains to point out minute details of the palace.

title: Changing of the guards
text: This is a much smaller palace as compared to the grand Gyeongbokgung palace and is in the heart of the city. We landed there just in time for the changing of the guards ceremony which is again not as elaborate as the one at Gyeongbokgung but is still nice. (You can watch the ceremony from the street. You need a ticket only to enter the palace grounds). The visit does not take much time as the palace grounds are small. The guide pointed out to us some of the structures dating back to 1600

title: Nice interiors, food was just ok
text: The interiors have an ethnic Indian look. The food we had for dinner starting from the soup was just about ok. The Indian touch was missing. Later, we came to know why, when we met the lady who runs the place. She is from South Korea and has visited India multiple times. She told us how she picked up tips on preparing Indian food during her visits and decided to start this venture. The decorative pieces for the interior were mostly from India. Full marks for the effort but just about 2.5 on 5 for the food. That is my unbiased assessment.

title: Unique architecture
text: This building symbolises modem South Korea with its futuristic design. The building  is lighted up in the night. Inside is a  kind of shopping mall with shops, restaurants and halls for exhibitions and cultural programs.

title: Traditional Korean houses
text: This is a residential area with hundreds of traditional Korean houses called hanoks. The area is open to visitors between 9 am and 5 pm. There are a number of alleys in the village through which you can take a walk. Though there are sign posts requesting tourists to keep their voices down so as to not disturb the residents, we found many tourists disregarding this. There are guards in the alleys who also keep making this request. There are lot of boutiques, souvenir shops and food stalls in the village. The walk was a very pleasant one and the architecture was unique. It felt like being a part of their homes and culture. A must do if you are in Seoul

title: A tale of two countries longing for unity
text:
The memorial show cases the long Korean war and the exhibits tell the history of the two Korea's and the devastation brought about by the war.

What is memorable is that despite the cold relations between the two countries, there is a longing for unity in the hearts of the citizens. These are well brought out by various sculptures on the lawns of the memorial. One very moving statue is is the 'Statue of brothers' where a South Korean Soldier hugs his younger brother who is serving in the North Korean army, on the battle field. This statue is on top of a dome with a wide crack, which symbolises the separation of the two Korea's and the hope for unification.

Fighter planes, tanks, artillery and naval weapons used in the Korean war are on display on the lawns of the memorial. A must visit if you are in Seoul

title: Spiritual
text:
Guided tours in English, German, Chinese and Japanese are available at particular time slots. Guide services are included in the entry ticket. You can enter the shrine only at these time slots as part of a guided tour. Tours in English are at 10 am, 12 noon, 2 pm and 4 pm. We reached there close to 11 am and had to wait for more than an hour to get in.

The shrine is where memorial service for the deceased kings and queens are held. The rituals continue even today. Annually, a big ceremony is held. The buildings are very simple. None of the grandeur associated with royalty. Not many exhibits . Would not term this as a must visit place
